I love this anime still. But it's by far my least like season of the 3. 
To start from the start i'll say the biggest problem with this for me .
How much this deviates a ton from the previous two seasons. Where those two were about the MC going around and getting girls to fall in love with him with funny scenarios. This season doesn't do that and decides to have one continues plot that last throughout the season. The plot itself could have been interesting but it's just eh at best for me. I like the idea of him having to go back andmake the girls he's already had fallen in love with him fall in love with him again. But it's badly done in this. 


The story also decides not to have him conqueor any girl at all and that is something i just don't like. Especially sense it's part of the identity of the show.


There is also the fact of how little we get of Elsie. By far top 3 characters in this show. It's honestly amazing how little we get of her considering she was the first girl introduced and is the MC's partner. 


We are suddenly given this rushed explanation on girls we've never seen before and the MC has made fall in love. Turns out that these are girls from the Manga that he'd conqeurored. But they for some reason didn't do any OVA's for these girls so we are then given these girls suddenly that we have no experiece with and are expected to have any care for. It honestly bugs me how they did this sense they seem to have interesting stories. 


One of the girls that were suddenly introduced i actually have a problem with. She and the MC had switched bodies and as a side effect or some dumb crap she has become boyish now and even dresses as a boy. She was originally a very girly type but now that personality is gone. It is the equivelant of killing someone. That girl and how she used to interact and how she viewed the world are now gone and replaced by a completely different girl. This honestly bugs me and i wish she stayed the same. Appearantly in her story she learned not to do what ever someone tells her. This is a message she could've learned without her original personallity being destroyed. 


Then there is the ending and this ending promtly explains why harem's in anime are always a bad thing. 


~~SPOILERS~~


Story seems to be going with Ayumi and personally i love her as a character and find he and the MC go together well. It also make sense with her being his first original conqeuor. Then Chihiro comes in and while i do like her. I just don't think she fits the MC at all and the fact the Mc seems to go for her kind of bugs me.


At the end we are shown the MC actually crying witch is something big for this guy. But it's over Chihiro and it can eitehr be because he actually likes her or because he feels bad about what he said to her. 


Either way it ruins an awesome moment with both the MC and Ayumi on the boat and them kissing each other while in wedding garb. I'd honestly love to see the Mc mary her and it should've ended there.


I have many issues with this ending and i'm not a fan that the MC and Ayumi don't seem like they will be a thing.


I still like Elsie and Huaqa more then any other and think they'd be the best romances.

~~SPOILERS OVER~~


Wish we got more of what i find to be the most interesting girls/conqeuors. They are the former Rich girl, Teacher and Karate girl. 


The former rich girl was interesting and wish we saw more of her. Still wish her story ended with her deciding to do well in school and take over her fathers buisiness on her own and become rich by her own merits.  Also wish they weren't living in a run down house.


The Teacher was awesome and interesting. I really liked her and wished she'd at least became a teacher at the school.


The karate girl was interesting because we saw both her personalities fighting each other. One wanting to be girly while the other not wanting to show any signs of weakeness. 


I feel these would've been nice to see in this or at least get more attention 


The ending also seems rushed. All of a sudden the final girl is being carted off and we are barely shown the final showdown or anything. 


Now before i go i still want to put out the idea that we need a parody  show of this. But have it with a girl accidently signing the contract and have her have to go and make other girls fall in love with her. This would be awesome and hilarious to see. Obviously we'd still need a girl partner as adorable as Elsie or almost.


Overall a good season but just not like the previous two.

I really liked the storyline and the girls in the anime fell in love with the MC for a good reason, unlike other harem anime where the girls simply fall in love for no particular amazing reason. However, the one thing I felt could be better was that the ending was rather forced. I still like the anime but the ending could have been left a bit more to the imagination of the viewers, allowing anyone to ship whoever they like. (Of course, there would probably be people who like the ending given.) In the end, it is not that I hate the Chihiro xKeima ship but the other female characters were pretty much discarded after their conquest, though their conquest stories were nice too. Also, I would like to state that Chihiro wasn't given a major role at the beginning; she was just another conquest target. Why did the creator choose Chihiro instead of any of the other female characters? Was there a poll of some sort? Was it just because she was his classmate?\n
All in all, my main point is the ending could be up to how ever the viewers want to end the story, rather than forcing everything to simply end with a single ship and 'The End'. (I feel that would end the whole story with a bad taste.)\n
Well, it is not like I have any right to criticise since I haven't created an anime or anything. I just wanted to state my opinion. I still really liked the anime though. The male MC was also really cool with his analytical thinking.

After having watched the first two seasons, I was wondering where this could possibly lead to. Not having read the manga or anything, I had no clue what I could expect other than the same thing. That is, the classic story of the guy conquering girls with his dating sim skills. And well, it sort of is, but not really. Instead of the usual, we get it served on a completely different platter, putting not only the story, but the characters in a completely different light, and making this season seem more realistic and gripping than anything that has happened so far.
"The World God OnlyKnows : Goddesses Arc" (or the Japanese title, whatever suits you best) is the third season of the Kami Nomi series. While I'm writing this review, this season is currently the highest ranked out of the three, and with good reason. In my review of the first season I wrote that it was silly and funny, with a hint of romance. This however appeals to only a part of the anime community, while the other part simply ignores it and moves on to more serious anime. This season feels like it sort of compensates for the goofy encounters and whatnot from the first two seasons, by providing us with actual relationships and returning characters who feel more solid than ever before, along with a more solid story.


Art:

The art is pretty much the same as the previous two seasons/OVAs, but with more flair added to it. You could consider calling them "special effects", but it does seem like more effort was put in the animation than before, along with some CG effects to add to the atmosphere. In overall, it felt more gripping, and at times it was quite stunning. The lighting in certain scenes was also excellently done, and provided a nice addition to the mood the scene was set in.


Music:

Different. This season was definitely meant to be taken far more seriously than the others, so the music had more of a thrill to it, and it succeeded quite well in moving me personally. Although I got to admit... I prefer the old OP, ED and BGM more. But that's my opinion as a RomCom SoL fan. If I were to look at it in the perspective of a more serious anime fanatic, I would say that it was great, and sometimes beautiful to listen to. (And yes, the last song moved me more than it should have, to those who have seen it.)


Story (Contains minor spoilers):

Assuming you're already familiar with the first two seasons and the OVAs (and if not, then I'd suggest you watch those first before even reading a review on this), the base of the story is still somewhat the same. We still have our main character (Katsuragi), his partner (Elsie), and the side cast from before. Some new characters were introduced, some rather rushed (due to shortening the story and leaving behind some backstories), and others more properly. We also get introduced to a few new groups: The Goddesses, who have taken refuge in the hearts of Katsuragi's previous "conquests", and Vintage, an evil group from Hell who wants to kill them.


I'm going to be honest here, this story was far more complicated than ever before. Due to the more active casting, and giving the side-characters more screentime (at least, that's what it felt like to me), it gave the story a lot more depth than it usually has. Combine that with the attitude and struggles of the main character, and you get something that doesn't really look like a Kami Nomi season, but sure as heck feels like it. It had this edgy undertone to it, with people actually being in danger this time and whatnot, but it wasn't all that unexpected. In fact, it was a great change of pace, and it all felt like it was building up to this season so far, using everything the first two seasons provided, and creating an arc that goes very well with the overall story.


Characters:

Like I said, the casting is very much the same, with the inclusion of the goddesses and the evil gang (which unfortunately doesn't get nearly the amount of screentime it deserves and needs). However, thanks to the character development this series had for over 25 episodes, they had a lot more depth to them. Which is good, otherwise you couldn't possibly take this plot seriously. Because as good as an arc it is, it relies mostly on the characters performing properly, otherwise it all falls apart into a messy piece of a RomCom. After all, and especially in this case, it's the characters that make the anime.


Conclusion:

What I personally liked about this anime, is that things didn't go nearly as smooth as it used to. The main character faces an old foe in a new jacket, as you might say, and every plan he used to have no longer works the way he wants it to. That's what makes the "Goddesses Arc" far more appealing to those who like to be surprised, and are tired of the same old stuff, while at the same time satisfying those who loved the anime from day 1, cause of its everlasting sillyness that exists even in this season, with the goofiest things happening at the most serious of times, allowing the audience to take a breather and smile. The third season combines the comedy we experienced before with a dose of drama it needed to balance itself out. A lot of anime have experienced the fate of repetitiveness, and it's thanks to this arc that this anime did not experience the same thing.


I was glad I watched this anime, and very satisfied with its (current) ending. If you haven't watched this season yet, I seriously recommend it. If you haven't watched the anime yet, and still bothered to read this review, go watch it, it's well worth your time. "The World God Only Knows" kept me at the edge of my seat, wanting to finish each season as soon as possible, simply because I enjoyed every minute of it. It never really disappointed me, and I hope that you'll feel the same thing when you watch it. After all, who doesn't want to take a peek in that world?
